user.biography: The official account of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a world leader in research, education, and innovation.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by MIT in Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.
Jordan Harrod is leaning against a green metal fence along the Charles River. She has one elbow on the fence and one hand on her hip.

node.text:
A researcher, writer, policy advocate, and YouTuber, Jordan Harrod is dedicated to communicating science. The HST doctoral student uses machine learning as a tool for studying pain and consciousness — and as subject matter for her popular videos. “I didn’t come into graduate school with a neuroscience background, so every day is an opportunity to learn new things about the brain. Even after three years, I’m still amazed with how much we have yet to discover.” Read about Jordan's journey, see link in profile.

Image: Adam Glanzman

#neuroscience #science #communications #consciousness #writer #BrainResearch #PolicyAdvocate #MachineLearning #HealthSciences #YouTuber
@mit_picower @mit_bcs

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by MIT on August 27, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person.

node.text:
#FlashbackFriday @MechE alum Ruth Heffernan Marsh ’85 is pictured above in this awesome photo as she races along the Charles during a regatta in her freshman year. Marsh—a member of the MIT sailing team for a year before switching to cross-country—recalls fond memories as part of the MIT sailing team:

“I can’t remember how well I or the team did on the day this photo was taken, but I do recall the team doing well that season. I have very fond memories of that fall—I loved the boathouse, the coaches, the camaraderie between the men’s and women’s teams. It was a place where I felt instantly comfortable and had some mastery while I was figuring out the whole MIT scene, which I found fairly intimidating that first year."

Repost @mit_engineering
Original source: @mitalumni Tech Reflection
.
.
.
alumni #students #engineer #engineering #sailing #Boston #Cambridge #CharlesRiver @mitsailing

node.accessibility_caption: Biology student Patricia Pujols is seated in a lab with mentor Ellen Guss, a doctoral student in Professor Troy Littleton's lab. Both wearing masks.

node.text:
A pivot from accounting to neuroscience: Through a summer research program at MIT, Patricia Pujols (seated) explored the neuromuscular junction, and a future in science. At MIT, Pujols says, “I stepped out of my comfort zone and strengthened my skills. MSRP gave me all the tools I needed to have an enriching experience in science, as well as the opportunity to meet colleagues that I will remember for the rest of my life.” Read about Patricia's journey, see link in profile.

Photo: Mandana Sassanfar

#biology #neuroscience #accounting #mentoring #research #science #neuromuscular @mit_bcs @mitscience

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by MIT on August 25, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
As our Summer internships draw to a close, we wanted to take some time to feature our incredible students and their work over the Summer. Next up is Graduate Student Mona VijayKumar (Architecture Studies and Urbanism, ‘22).

Mona was born and raised in Chennai, India, but her ancestral roots are in Jodhpur, India. “Growing up in India, I have firsthand witnessed the persistent inequalities, especially towards care, shelter, and education, that shape the lives of people in developing countries,” said Mona, “My vision for social egalitarianism and just society propelled me to pursue research about the Agariyan community and Little Rann of Kutch as part of the MISTI India Fellowship.”

Mona’s research aims to empower the under-represented salt worker community in the Little Rann of Kuchh, India. “The community, locally called Agariyas, live in extreme climatic conditions for 8 months every year with a lack of access to basic human necessities-- shelter, school, medical care, and sanitation. While conducting interviews with local NGOs in the region, the necessity to provide a shelter that could withstand the extreme weather conditions while also being temporary and affordable became the priority,” Mona told us. “Through Project ‘Chaaya’ (translates to shade), I seek to co-design a temporary shelter prototype that is easy to deploy, assemble, and affordable. A shelter that is climate-responsive and environmentally sustainable. The implementation strategy is to first engage with the community members in a workshop session to co-design iterations of the prototype. The second would be to deploy the shelter kits and design catalog, followed by building a pilot shelter with the community.”
 
Mona’s advice to those considering studying with MIT-India? “MIT-India is a great opportunity for one to dive deeper into their area of interest and connect with local partner organizations. It also provides training modules that allow one to learn more about India from its various lenses of people, culture, politics, and geography.”
 
Connect with Mona on LinkedIn here: https://www.linkedin.com/in/mona-vijaykumar-a73216124/

Reposted from @mit_india
 
#mitstudents #mitalumni #gomisti

node.accessibility_caption: A close up shot of Martin Nisser. He is looking toward his right.
An inflatable robotic hand holds a cupcake and a human hand reaches to grab it.

node.text:
Prosthetic hands have come a long way, but their high-tech dexterity comes at a price. Now engineers have designed a soft, inflatable, low-cost neuroprosthetic hand that lets users perform daily activities as well as those with heavier prosthetics. “This is not a product yet, but the performance is already similar or superior to existing neuroprosthetics, which we’re excited about,” says Xuanhe Zhao, professor of mechanical engineering and of civil and environmental engineering at MIT. “There’s huge potential to make this soft prosthetic very low cost, for low-income families who have suffered from amputation.” Read about the research, see link in profile.

#prosthetics #engineering #engineers #amputation #neuroprosthetics #3DPrinting #AssistiveTechnology #robotics #MedicalDevices #sensors #WearableSensors @mit_cee @mitmeche

node.accessibility_caption: Liquid droplets resembles Harold “Doc” Edgerton’s high-speed photos of a bullet fired through an apple.

node.text:
High-speed camera captures a water jet’s splashy impact as it pierces a droplet: The results may help engineers develop a way to inject drugs without needles. “We want to explore how needle-free injection can be done in a way that minimizes damage to the skin,” says David Fernandez Rivas, a research affiliate at MIT and professor at the University of Twente. “With these experiments, we are getting all this knowledge, to inform how we can create jets with the right velocity and shape to inject into skin.” Read about the research, see link in profile.

Photo: Courtesy of researchers, and Tiny Giants

#DrugDelivery #MedicalDevices #microfluids #research @mit_engineering

node.accessibility_caption: Hyunwoo Yuk, Jingjing Wu, and Xuanhe Zhao holding the barnacle shell and the barnacle-glue-inspired hemostatic paste in hands.

node.text:
MIT engineers led by Professor Xuanhe Zhao (right), Dr. Hyunwoo Yuk (left), and Dr. Jingjing Wu have designed a strong, biocompatible glue that can seal injured tissues and stop bleeding, inspired by the sticky substance that barnacles use to cling to rocks.

📸: Courtesy of the researchers

Reposted from @mitmeche

Read about the research: https://news.mit.edu/2021/barnacle-glue-wound-seal-0809

#research #bioinspiration #barnacles #adhesive #medicine

node.accessibility_caption: Laureen wears a blue jacket and stands next to equipment used to scrap aluminum plus water to generate the flow of hydrogen needed for a particular practical application.

node.text:
Hydrogen could help wean the world off fossil fuels — but its production typically generates carbon. Laureen Meroueh PhD ’20 and others funded by @MITEnergy are exploring whether clean hydrogen fuel could be made by reacting aluminum with water. Read about the research, see link in profile.

Photo: Reza Mirshekari

#hydrogen #aluminum #FossilFuels #HydrogenFuel #energy #ScrapAluminum
